item.title: Report E-2025020238
item.description:
Report E-2025020238

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-19T06:18:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: WEST SACRAMENTO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 13, 2025, one (1) 1-liter bottle of nitric acid was damaged and released approximately one (1) liter of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services who dispatched a crew from Graymar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. GES crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area and worked it in with hand tools until a neutral pH reading was confirmed. The damaged bottle and box were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. The PPE and neutralizing agent were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020236
item.description:
Report E-2025020236

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 13, 2025, two (2) 5-gallon pails of paint were punctured and released approximately 0.25-gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized cleaning agents and absorbents to remove the released paint. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 15-gallon drum and the damaged pails were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 14, 2025, one (1) 1-gallon jug of UN1789 was punctured and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and a neutralizing agent to remediate the UN1789-impacted loading dock floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into two (2) 35-gallon drums and staged onsite.

  • Description: On February 13, 2025, two (2) 50-pound bags of sodium hydroxide were torn in transit and released approximately two (2) ounces of product to the trailer interior. The trailer was unloaded, and a tote of sodium bisulfite was found to be missing a bung, which is the suspected source of the powder. The container was closed properly and received at the facility.

item.title: Report E-2025020232
item.description:
Report E-2025020232

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-19T06:18:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-15
  • City: JACKSON
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 116000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 15, 2025, at 1602 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Inway personnel in Jackson, TN regarding the release of several hazardous materials. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 48 pounds of UN3106 Organic Peroxide type D, 5.2, II from (5) 10-lbs plastic pails, 12 gallons of UN1866 Resin solution, 3, II from (2) 6-gallon metal pails, 80 gallons of UN1760 Corrosive liquids, 8, III from (16) 5-gallon metal pails, and 90 gallons of non-regulated Tremco Epoxy Primer Part A from (18) 5-gallon metal pails onto the ground. The release was reportedly due to a rollover accident during transit, impacting multiple areas of soil and asphalt. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The release was cleaned up with the proper PPE. Contractors removed the damaged product and repalletized the good product. All waste generated from addressing this release was placed into roll-off containers, which were taken off site by the contractor for proper disposal.

  • City: LOUISVILLE

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ABF Operation Supervisor Teddy Trautwein states that all the employees went to break at the same time and while they were on break, a 55 gallon drum of UN1263, Paint, 3 Unknown PG began to leak in the storage area near dock door 43. ABF Supervisor states that the puncture looks to be from a forklift blade but none of his workers have owned up to it yet. Safety advised that we would need to know the forklift operator ASAP if he finds out and to pull CCTV video to find the suspect. Teddy emailed ABF Hazmat stating that one of his employees, Trevor Story, may have accidentally punctured the drum while trying to off load a hazmat tote from dock door 52 that's awaiting billing. Safety responded stating that we'll need to pull some CCTV to confirm this but he's currently a possible source of the spill. ABF Supervisor states that hazmat pro 069559511 was involved in the spill so Safety contacte d ABF069 and spoke with Supervisor Ronald Thompson and he clarified that the shipment only got paint on the shrink wrap and was not actively leaking.

  • Description: On February 13, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from American Safety, LLC (AS) to remediate the site. AS personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the impacted impacted trailer and pavement. One (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 was placed into one (1) 95-gallon poly over-pack, and all spent absorbents, PPE, and cleanup debris were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum.

item.description:
Report E-2025020191

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T03:17:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-12
  • City: COLONIAL HEIGHTS
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 12, 2025, one (1) 600-pound pressurized tank of UN3500 was crushed in transit and released approximately 5-ounces of product to the dock floor and pallet. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the UN3500-impacted loading dock floor. After remediating the product released on the pallet and loading dock, the crew utilized a forklift to move the leaking tank into an open well ventilated area. The damaged tank was labeled with a non-haz waste label and all impacted material was collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.

item.title: Report I-2025010003
item.description:
Report I-2025010003

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-29
  • City: SEADRIFT
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: DOW Chemical-Watco Yard
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 11/29/24 at approximately 23:00 conductor notified !he yardmaster on duty that they had located a leaking Anhydrous Ammonia rail car, STPX 220216. Yardmaster immediately had the crew clear the area and escalated to DOW EH&S who responded and attempted to secure the car and stop the leak. EH&S was unable to stop the leak and Specialized Response Solutions was contacted for remediation. SRS arrived on scene and began to work on the leak. The vapor valve was found to be leaking through the bonnet and the secondary closure plug after being unloaded and moved to a storage yard. Dow's Emergency Response Team responded and attempted to repair the leak by tightening the valve handle but found that the handle was stripped. The valve handle was removed to be replaced by another valve handle. After removal of the stripped handle the valve stem was found to be rounded off. This prevented the addition of closure pressure without gouging the valve shaft. The response team used a 24-inch pipe wrench and was able to apply a small amount of force that only minimally affected the leak volume through the bonnet. The Dow ER team was considering installing the Midland Emergency Response Kit (ERK) but the protective housing only had three port holes therefore the capping kit strongback would not connect properly. SRS crew returns to the tank car to construct and install a vapor scrubber and install a containment bag over the vapor valve. The internal pressure of the car is approximately 85 psig. The two-tote vapor scrubber is set up and operational. While the crew was preparing to place a containment bag over the vapor valve the decision was made to loosen the valve faceplate and release the pressure contained in the body of the valve. This would simplify the installation of the containment bag over the vapor valve. Crew removes the vapor valve faceplate. Minimal pressure is heard leaking through the sealing surface of the valve. The crew find that the seat disc (gasket) installed in the seat disc retainer assembly has been partially dislodged. The seat disc has been crushed by force being applied to the valve stem. Without removal of all pressure from the tank car the leak would not be repaired Crew attempted to install the capping kit gasket between the vapor valve and the magnetic gauging rod flange assembly. Although the gasket would not fit the crew decided to shave the side of the gasket and try again with no success. Decision made to remove the magnetic gauging rod flange and shave one quarter inch off the edge of the flange facing the vapor valve. The nuts securing the protective housing outer ring are removed and the outer ring is rotated 90 degrees to provide port holes for the capping kit strong back. Midland capping kit is successfully installed. As pressure in the can increases the pressure is sent to the scrubber while seating the gasket confirming containment. This is being done due to the defective sealing surface and corrosion on the surface of the

item.title: Report I-2024120044
item.description:
Report I-2024120044

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-18
  • City: BURLINGTON
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: QSA GLOBAL, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 11/18/2024 at 13:40 pm, QSA Global, Inc. received an undeclared hazardous material shipment from Samsung Vietnam on behalf of Neadtech, JSC. The outer packaging was a shrink-wrapped cardboard box designed to contain a rice cooker. It was suspected that this package may contain a radioactive container. It was moved to the "Radioactive Shipping/Receiving" area of the facility. Upon opening the package, it was discovered that the package contained a modified Type A Model 650L source changer with a depleted Se-75 source (0.12 Ci). The rice cooker box did not contain the proper DOT required markings/labels for radioactive material or for an overpack. The Model 650L had no radiation labeling present, was painted red and the nameplate was not visible due to the paint. The paint mimicked the coloring of the rice cooker pictured on the outer packaging. Neadtech, JSC neither forwarded the 7 Day Advance Notification Form (F-C-3190-002) to QSA Global, Inc. as required for approval of an import of radioactive material, nor informed QSA Global, Inc. of the returning shipment. Radiation Surveys of the Model 650L were within regulatory limits, and no contamination was present. There was no release and no failure of the package other than the unlawful modification and incorrect shipment classification & labeling. Please note for ques. 25 on this form, there are no failure codes associated with RAM packages within the DOT Incident Form F 5800.1 instructions.

  • Description: A 30 gallon metal drum of lighters was being shipped under special permit 13179. At the time of the incident the drum was on a pallet and had been removed from a 48' van trailer and was to be moved from one pallet to another to be placed back on the 48' van trailer for further transportation. There was no other handling to take place. As an employee grabbed the drum by hand to move it the lid blew off hitting the employee. There was no continued release of butane. The butane that had accumulated in the drum did flash and it is estimated that all the butane was used in the flash. No release, nor continued release of butane was observed. A single butane torch appears to have been defective and caused the incident. As the lighters were being repackaged a butane torch was ignited just by moving it. The lock was found to be defective. The torch was made inoperable by taping the valve closed.

  • Description: BNE Driver was involved in fatal vehicle accident while traveling east bound on NJ Route 3 (Clifton, NJ), -Lat 40.8673383, Long -74.184025479. At the time of the accident the EE was driving BNE tractor #476 and loaded BNE van trailer #159. After coming in contact with a NJ Transit Bus, the vehicle went off the right side of the roadway, struck the guardrail, and went through a sound barrier wall creating a fire engulfing the tractor, spreading to the trailer, and resulted in fire and two explosions of onboard hazmat (various flammable liquids, and corrosive) freight. The EE succumbed to their injuries. Roadway was closed for several hours and Local Clifton Fire Dept was able to extinguish the fire of the vehicle, trailer and freight. First Call Environmental (ER/Environmental) contractor was able to contain, remediate, and clean-up the affected areas impacted by fire and release of hazmat at direction of EPA and NJDEP.

item.title: Report I-2024070112
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-17
  • City: RIVERDALE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 313220
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: An East Penn Manufacturing Co. driver was heading west bound on Kamm Ave approaching Jameson Ave. The other driver was headed northbound on Jameson Ave. approaching Kamm Ave. The other driver disregarded the posted stop sign and came into the path of the East Penn driver. Collision occurred and the East Penn truck rolled on to its side and came to a final stop at the northwest corner of the intersection. This was a T-Bone event. Police came to the scene and requested help for the cleanup. East Penn hired a hazardous waste cleanup contractor to clean up the batteries that were on the ground and take them back to their shop. East Penn then went back to the contractor to pick up the batteries to take them back to East Penn's Salt Lake City, UT facility. The batteries were then sent to one of the East Penn's tolling smelters for proper disposal of the batteries at a secondary lead smelter for recycle. East Penn also hired a contractor to do the remediation cleanup of the soil and incident area. The clean up was completed and overseen by the Fresno County Enviromental Health.
